metadata.name: Slumbers #247
metadata.description:
Generative abstract artwork that explores forms, shapes, coloring and brushwork.

Options:

- press 'f' to turn off paper-like texture (recommended for print on hi-quality paper)
- press 's' to save the PNG image of the current view
- press 1, 2, 3, or 4 to save hi-res PNG images

Colors and textures might differ slightly on some devices due to the heavy use of low alpha blending. Calibrated and tested on Firefox 107.0 & Chrome 107.0.5304.107 on Win10 x64 Intel machine.

Created using p5js.

@VolatileMoods, November, 2022.
tags: slumbers volatile moods abstract generative painting colors brushwork

metadata.name: Botanical Ghosts #279
metadata.description:
This is a work about growth, impermanence and decay. Ghostly plants and flowers grow around an invisible point, but they immediately begin to fade into the dark background and are soon replaced and covered by others. This process of accumulation and disappearance builds an ever-changing floral garland, or perhaps a funeral wreath.

The monochrome vegetation is part of a fictional flora, born out of random algorithmic combinations, and does not intend to reproduce any real species. It belongs to an ‚Äúartificial nature‚Äù which, like so many worlds that the computers generate for us in movies, games, and virtual reality environments, is a convincing simulation of life, but it is not actually living. AI bots, virtual assistants and non-player characters are also representatives of the uncanny realm of the not-really-alive-but-looking-like-it, which are becoming an increasingly relevant presence in our everyday lives.

These plants and flowers speak about life as a process of incessant renovation, but also about death as the background that‚Äôs always there and makes life possible. This spectral vegetation seems to thrive precisely at the verge between both worlds.
_______________


This work is animated and will adapt to any screen size. It generates a never-ending ring of algorithmic foliage, which never repeats itself, and is different for each token. The image preview is triggered after the first five plants or flowers.
Made with p5.js

Controls:
[SPACE] to play/pause
[f] to toggle fullscreen
[s] to download capture

metadata.name: Gestalt #380
metadata.description:
"Gestalt" is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at The Ever-Evolving World of Art, Art Basel Hong-Kong, 2022

A flurry of many elements derived from my past (and future) strewn across a single canvas. As random as things seem, collectively time tends to reveal hints of order in the chaos. Sometimes, more is more.

Controls:
‚Ä¢ Left-click/tap reassembles the piece with one less element each time
‚Ä¢ 'R' reassembles the piece with all elements
‚Ä¢ 'S' saves the output

‚ÄúùöÉùöëùöé ùö†ùöëùöòùöïùöé ùöíùöú ùöêùöõùöéùöäùöùùöéùöõ ùöùùöëùöäùöó ùöùùöëùöé ùöúùöûùöñ ùöòùöè ùöíùöùùöú ùöôùöäùöõùöùùöú.‚Äù

Made in p5js
Created May 2022
Artist: @Yazid

metadata.name: Glossolalia #5
metadata.description:
This series is ultimately about catharsis. The compositions can be chaotic and maybe even a little messy, but they also can be vibrant and diverse‚Ä¶ which is really what this is trying to celebrate: diversity and expression.

Simply, it‚Äôs about the emotions associated with whatever frees you.

Please see the linked fxtext article (on the main project page) for a more in-depth dissection of the concept. It‚Äôs less of a technical discussion, and more about the experience of the artist, and how it became linked with the feelings they associate with the art.

In live mode:

For higher resolutions, you can append ‚Äú&density=2‚Äù to the url to double the size, ‚Äú&density=3‚Äù to triple, and so on.
(This is highly recommended.)

To adjust grain, you can append ‚Äú&grain=##‚Äù to the url. 40 is the default, and 0 will remove it completely.

metadata.name: Adjacent #100
metadata.description:
Adjacent is the third in a set of collections based on a month-long study of Edward Zajec, one of the early pioneers of generative art. This piece focuses on the study of Diagonal White, a series he developed between 1970 and 1975.

In 1976, Ruth Leavitt published a collection of papers titled "Artist & Computer", which highlighted the 35 prominent generative artists and asked them to discuss their work. They were posed questions like, "Do you feel art work created with a computer has now or will have an impact on art as a whole in the future?". Edward Zajec was a subject of one of those papers and in it detailed the approach to Diagonal White. 

The original program was run on a CDC 6200 computer at The Univeresiry of Trieste. The programming was done in collaboration with Dr. Matjaz Hmeljak, his long-time technical partner. Inspired by his collaborative relationship, Adjacent the output of a partnership between Christine Hall and Chris Maddern.

Controls (in live view):
- Press [s] to save a high-resolution version of the image

Made in p5js
Created January 2023
By @christine_hall and @chrismaddern

metadata.name: Eucalyptus and Sagebrush #150
metadata.description:
Eucalyptus and Sagebrush is inspired by the eucalyptus trees and sagebrush found in California. These plants, and the hills they inhabit, have long been a source of beauty and adventure in my life, and I find myself repeatedly drawn back to them. The sunsets in coastal California are a perfect compliment to these hills, and I set out to represent that combination in this work.

Each iteration of this algorithm feels, to me, like a glimpse out of a car window on a drive up the coast, a pause on a cool morning hike, or a memory of tearing through sharp underbrush with good company.

Stylistically and texturally, I drew from landscapes rendered in oil pastels, placing thousands of tiny circles, alluding to the effect of depositing particles of color onto paper. 

I hope that this work evokes in the viewer the feelings of peace, wildness, and adventure that I feel when I watch the sun set over these hills.

Nat Sarkissian


Notes:
- Append ‚Äú&mag=N‚Äù to the end of the URL in live mode to specify a resolution multiplier. It will render the image N times larger than the size of your window. If you have specified anything greater than 1, a download will start automatically once the rendering is done. The maximum resolution seems to be limited by what your web browser allows. I have been able to output up to 11140px tall and wide using Firefox, which should be enough detail for prints up to 37x37 inches. I recommend keeping the console open while attempting larger renders. It will show you if you have attempted too large a render for your system. N can be any positive whole or decimal number greater than or equal to 1.

metadata.name: Specter of Fears #22
metadata.description:
In the dreamlike landscape of our minds, the specter of fears is like a wraith, ever-present and ethereal. It whispers in our ear, reminding us of all the things we dare not face. It is a shadow that falls across our hearts, casting a pall of doubt and uncertainty. But even as it haunts us, we must remember that it is a part of us. We must learn to accept its presence, and to use it to our advantage. For fear is not always a curse, it is a guide that shows us where we must grow stronger. It is a companion that walks with us through the dark night, illuminating the path ahead. By embracing our fears, we find the courage to face them, and to overcome them. We find the strength to live fully, to love fiercely, and to pursue our dreams with abandon.

Controls :

‚Ä¢ Press 1, 2, 3, or 4 to make a capture and download a PNG with a resolution of x1, x2, x3 or x4.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Specter of Fears by Ferdinand Dervieux, 2023
Made with Unity
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Clerestory #58
metadata.description:
Windows welcome daylight, admit fresh air, and offer a view into the outside world. They rarely shatter, always confess the passage of time, and sometimes allow others a chance to look in.

What would the space you're in feel like if it had no windows?

'Clerestory' is an abstract exploration of stained glass windows, drafting shattered sketches for ten potential locations from various perspectives and moments in time. 

Made with WebGL, p5.js, and <3 | CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Genuary 32nd - Wimondrian #10
metadata.description:
Project for #Genuary32
Prompt: grid inside a grid inside a grid

---

Variations in this generative art use different sizes, shapes, and colors in grids.
Inspired by modernism era artists: Wim Crouwel and Piet Mondrian style

metadata.name: Crosswalk Monsoon #96
metadata.description:
The story behind this collection is that there isn't really a story behind this collection. It is the result of play, tinkering, and curiosity.

One of the beautiful things about generative art is how we can achieve drastically different results simply by modifying a few parameters or lines of code. As my first release here on fxhash was 'Sabler', it felt fitting that my release for #fxhashturnsone would itself be a modified version of that 'Sabler' algorithm, albeit giving drastically different results.

It is notable for the fact that this is perhaps my most 'chaotic' collection yet, letting go of carefully considered proportions, angles and positioning and here leaving that in the hands of the computer. In a way, this simple act represents several design decisions I never would have imagined myself making a year ago, highlighting my growth as a generative artist over the past year.

It is also a reflection of the inspiration gained from many of the artists and boundary-pushers in the space that each time unlock and encourage creations beyond the immediate comfort zone. For that, this is a 'Thank You' to all of you.

With that, here's to many more years of generative beauty and inspiration on fxhash and beyond.

As with previous collections, I highly recommend viewing the images at full size and savouring the details and the chaos up close. Pressing 'S' will save a 6000 x 6000 px PNG file.

50% of primary sales will be donated to the Processing Foundation.

metadata.name: Perpendicular Inhabitation #80
metadata.description:
'Perpendicular Inhabitation' is a generative collection exploring the relationship between the urban landscape and the human experience, particularly feelings of nostalgia and more specifically 'anemoia' : the feeling of nostalgia for a time or place that we may not have actually experienced first hand. 

Despite depicting a stylised modern architectural language, at its core the collection serves as a homage to 1980s Japan, an era of unprecedented prosperity that left a lasting impression on the music and artwork of the time. Through the use of carefully created palettes and composition, the outputs intend to evoke feelings of optimism, while guiding viewers to consider why the essence of this era is so alluring in the present day as it continues to influence and inspire contemporary art.

The use of exaggerated perpendicular verticals, as well as the heavily foreshortened mountain ranges present in some outputs, convey a sense of hope and possibility for the future. What does it feel like to hope and dream in the city? To look up and be filled with a sense of wonder from the built environment around you?

This project has been created with print in mind at a ratio of 3:4

It is recommended to examine your outputs at full size in order to enjoy them to the fullest.

You are encouraged to return often to notice things you may not have seen previously.

Generated with code using p5.js

Images are generated at 2400 x 3200 px. 

To save a PNG file, please press 'S'.

Depending on the complexity of each output, please wait up to 10 seconds for the image generation to complete.

metadata.name: Across Paper Stones #62
metadata.description:
Wherever you want to go, you'll find a path to take you there.

Each tile is made up of two deformed rectangles. One is drawn with a drifting, fragmented outline.

Over thirty color palettes are shuffled together on each output, helping form slight edges between groups.

Created by Eric Davidson. 2022.

metadata.name: Here, After #86
metadata.description:
We were all there
when the sky cried confetti
and if we weren‚Äôt, we felt like we had
but here, after
held with each other‚Äôs eyes
not much is said at all

‚Äî‚Äî

A : Animate rendering
S : Save current resolution
1 -> 5 : Save low -> high resolution

metadata.name: Erasing Memories [diptych] #40
metadata.description:
With love for the New York School & abstract expressionism.

's' in live mode to save in png.

Tomeo - Jan 2022
